description:
Hello

Since we launched the Games-time site, the schools map on Get Set has been empty: http://getset.london2012.com/en/map/get-set-network-schools-and-colleges

This is because we used to host the updated list of schools as a .csv file on the old website which is picked up by the Stamen map trying to download from

http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/education/get-set-maps/images/schools.csv

This Url does not exist any more which is why stamen is showing an empty map.  The data can of course be found on the Kitsite site as education are still publishing to this.

We cannot apparently host .csv files on the new site CMS. Can you advise if there is another URL where we can host this? Gold is an option - but this site should really be behind a password. Could it sit, for example, on the Learning Legacy or Festival CMS?

Grateful for your thoughts!

Morag Reavley
Senior New Media Manager
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games
1 Churchill Place
Canary Wharf
London
Direct dial: 020 32012 160
Reception: 020 32012 000

<hr width="100%">

comments.value:
Hello

Since we launched the Games-time site, the schools map on Get Set has been empty: http://getset.london2012.com/en/map/get-set-network-schools-and-colleges

This is because we used to host the updated list of schools as a .csv file on the old website which is picked up by the Stamen map trying to download from

http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/education/get-set-maps/images/schools.csv

This Url does not exist any more which is why stamen is showing an empty map.  The data can of course be found on the Kitsite site as education are still publishing to this.

We cannot apparently host .csv files on the new site CMS. Can you advise if there is another URL where we can host this? Gold is an option - but this site should really be behind a password. Could it sit, for example, on the Learning Legacy or Festival CMS?

Grateful for your thoughts!

Morag Reavley
Senior New Media Manager
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games
1 Churchill Place
Canary Wharf
London
Direct dial: 020 32012 160
Reception: 020 32012 000

<hr width="100%">
The London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games Limited
A company registered in England and Wales with its registered office at One Churchill Place, Canary Wharf, London E14 5LN and registered number 05267819 
          
This E-mail is confidential.  If you are not the addressee you may not copy, forward, disclose or use any part of it. If you have received this message in error, please delete it and all copies from your system and notify the sender immediately by return
E-mail.
             
Nothing in this message or its attachments is intended to create legal relations between us unless there is an express statement creating such relations or this message contains an authorised purchase order.
                                     
Internet communications cannot be guaranteed to be timely secure, error or virus-free. The sender does not accept liability for any errors or omissions.

http://www.london2012.com
<hr width="100%">

Hi Morag,

"We cannot apparently host .csv files on the new site CMS"

(clears throat...)

I am sure we can allow access to gold on a per directory or url basis (just liaising with Kieran as he has been working on setting this up) 

To be honest I can't see any security issues round this, those server are still active, serving live/current sites (so server/app security should be maintained as before) and all the assets on that server have previously been published/public. The danger I assume is old content reappearing when it shouldn't, particularly in search engines, however we implemented a robots.txt file (no Google indexing) and a password to stop casual browsing and spiders/robots (that ignore robots.txt rules) indexing the site.

In short, I can't see any danger in allowing access direct access to any "non page" asset (img, csv, js etc.) on gold (other than a direct link there will be no way of finding this content), but even if we don't go that far we can certainly allow access to that single url without a password (which would seem the most sensible route).

We'll get it setup today and let you know the url

Jamie

Hi Morag,

We're just allowing some exceptions to the password restriction on Gold.

GetSet should be able to use this url (same as before just has www changed to gold)
http://gold.london2012.com/get-involved/education/get-set-maps/images/schools.csv

Jamie

Fantastic – thanks for this.

Do you know when this will be effective from?

You can use it straight away, 

We're actually going to be further restricting access to gold via passwords (ongoing work today/tomorrow), but we'll just leave this url as one of the exceptions.
Perfect – thank you!

Hi Tuesday,

We'll get it changed back, 

But you can't say we didnt' warn you, see below :-)

(in fact Kieran also wrote a lengthy email on why ditching relevance was a bad idea as well)

ps. we did also outline (below) the correct way to do what you want, which is to get GDP to 'weight' the results by age bracket ie. 1 day, 1 week, 1 month (this is very different from just sorting all the results in date order). Unfortunately this change needs to be made a GDP's end.

Jamie 

==============

Jamie Unwin, Apr 19 02:10 pm (BST):

Wahome,

Are you *sure* that won't just sort the results in date order, in effect throwing away any relevance?

For example if I search for "Jazz" 
http://festival.london2012.com/events/search.php?categoryIds=&searchString=jazz&searchLocation=Town+or+Postcode&startDate=From+Date&endDate=To+Date&event-search-submit=Find+Events

Then I currently get the results back in relevance order with the event that best matches (or matches the most times) for the word "Jazz" ie. Wynton Marsalis' Swing Symphony

However if I sorted the results by date, the last result may appear first, which happens to be a screening of silent Hitchcock films, which most people who search for Jazz probably think is totally irrelevant (it appears due to the line "Sawhney is an Indian-British musician, producer and composer whose critically acclaimed work combines Asian and other worldwide influences with elements of jazz and electronica." in other words it has no real relevance to the event)
http://festival.london2012.com/events/9000961780

As it is if we add in a (sortedBy=DATE) parameter we get Pina Bausch at the top (which while not as obscure as a match for Hitchcock isn't far of in terms of not being what you'd expect at the top result)
http://festival.london2012.com/events/search.php?categoryIds=&searchString=jazz&searchLocation=Town+or+Postcode&startDate=From+Date&endDate=To+Date&sortedBy=DATE&event-search-submit=Find+Events
I mention this as it the one of the thing we are always asked to change (when we build free text searches) and then asked to change back once the client realises that sorting a list of results (that are already sorted by relevance) is not what they want.

As Kieran said, we know exactly what you want to do and why, but just sorting your (already sorted by relevance) results by dates will result in you losing the relevance order.

The correct solution is to weight the results on both relevance + age (banding) so that the results become a mix of age+relevance (this is what Google does, the main www site search does and what you tend to expect when searching for News, Event or any other date based results)

Simply date sorting your relevance sorted results, post relevant ordering, will simply result in the relevance information being lost.

Happy to do it, just wanted to point out that it might not be what is expected / the pitfalls, before we did it..

Jamie

==============

Wahome Muchiri, Apr 19 04:01 pm (BST):

Jamie, I'll let you know final word when I round up reactions from Festival
marketers.

My view is that unlike main 2012 site (and def google), Festival content is
very limited and highly focused that keyword searches will almost always
return relevant results, even if not perfect (as with jazz). And since all
the content is events, the main priority is to order them by immediacy for
attendance, which would also maintain a consistent experience on the events
serp page regardless of how you land there.

==============

Hi Jamie

Thank you for your suggestions. I did ask GDP about this and of course there are cost implications if we add weight to the results so if we could change it back to relevance for now, I think it would sort part of the problem. I will discuss with Claire how we will proceed.

Many thanks,

Tuesday

Hi again,

Claire asked if we can change it asap please because our advertising and brochure’s out. Many many thanks!

Tuesday

Hi Tuesday,

This should be back to how it was originally now.

Jamie

description:
Requesting bug fix: results returned from free-form search aren't
ordered chronologically, unlike the canned searches by category.

E.g. search for 'shakespeare' and results aren't ordered by date, but
'Theatre' events via the categories filter returns an ordered set.

Thanks.
subject: Bug: ordering of Festival search results

comments.value:
Requesting bug fix: results returned from free-form search aren't
ordered chronologically, unlike the canned searches by category.

E.g. search for 'shakespeare' and results aren't ordered by date, but
'Theatre' events via the categories filter returns an ordered set.

Thanks.

Hi Wahome,

I think Jamie might have replied to this in a previous ticket/conversation.
Freetext searches are ordered by relevance. I'm not sure exactly what algorithm GDP use but if you search for "Shakespeare" then it is likely that events that mention "Shakespeare" more than once will appear near the top of the results, and ones that only mention him once will appear towards the end of the results.

If you wish we can order freetext searches by date BUT this has the downside that it orders by date, REGARDLESS OF RELEVANCE. If this is what you want then that's fine but I'm just making you aware that it has the potential to be confusing for users. (I can see why you want date-ordering though, so don't think I'm trying to dissuade you from this course of action!)

Kieran

Hi Wahome,

I expect that's because they are returned based on match relevance (which unless two results are /identical/ will override any chronological order *)

Remember we just return whatever we get back from GDP's API, if they return them in that order that is how they will be displayed.

(* the problem is how do you tell if an exact match from 1 year ago is more or less relevant that a partial match yesterday? Or put another way if we just chronologically sorted the results you'd lose the relevance order? One way to get round this - and we do this on the main www site search - is to weight the results with a age banding ie. 1 day, 1 week, 1 month etc. which is then added into the score and hence the order. But we'd require GDP to incorporate this kind of weighting at their end, we can't add it at our end as we receive the results in a paginated fashion)
(two answers for the price of one! we're both saying approximately the same thing though)

Kieran, Jamie, thanks. The algorithm was recently changed to query events
by all attributes, rather than a select few in the past (name, venue,
categories), but this still doesn't predicate the ordering which is left to
the client. So suggest you include this parameter in your call
"&sortedBy=DATE". I think given the way the site works it's best to view
results chronologically.

Wahome,

Are you sure that won't just sort the results in date order, in effect throwing away any relevance?

For example if I search for "Jazz" 
http://festival.london2012.com/events/search.php?categoryIds=&searchString=jazz&searchLocation=Town+or+Postcode&startDate=From+Date&endDate=To+Date&event-search-submit=Find+Events

Then I currently get the results back in relevance order with the event that best matches (or matches the most times) for the word "Jazz" ie. Wynton Marsalis' Swing Symphony 

However if I sorted the results by date, the last result may appear first, which happens to be a screening of silent Hitchcock films, which most people who search for Jazz probably think is totally irrelevant (it appears due to the line "Sawhney is an Indian-British musician, producer and composer whose critically acclaimed work combines Asian and other worldwide influences with elements of jazz and electronica." in other words it has no real relevance to the event)
http://festival.london2012.com/events/9000961780

As it is if we add in a (sortedBy=DATE) parameter we get Pina Bausch at the top (which while not as obscure as a match for Hitchcock isn't far of in terms of not being what you'd expect at the top result)
http://festival.london2012.com/events/search.php?categoryIds=&searchString=jazz&searchLocation=Town+or+Postcode&startDate=From+Date&endDate=To+Date&sortedBy=DATE&event-search-submit=Find+Events

I mention this as it the one of the thing we are always asked to change (when we build free text searches) and then asked to change back once the client realises that sorting a list of results (that are already sorted by relevance) is not what they want.

As Kieran said, we know exactly what you want to do and why, but just sorting your (already sorted by relevance) results by dates will result in you losing the relevance order.

The correct solution is to weight the results on both relevance + age (banding) so that the results become a mix of age+relevance (this is what Google does, the main www site search does and what you tend to expect when searching for News, Event or any other date based results)

Simply date sorting your relevance sorted results, post relevant ordering, will simply result in the relevance information being lost.

Happy to do it, just wanted to point out that it might not be what is expected / the pitfalls, before we did it..

Jamie

Jamie, I'll let you know final word when I round up reactions from Festival
marketers.

My view is that unlike main 2012 site (and def google), Festival content is
very limited and highly focused that keyword searches will almost always
return relevant results, even if not perfect (as with jazz). And since all
the content is events, the main priority is to order them by immediacy for
attendance, which would also maintain a consistent experience on the events
serp page regardless of how you land there.

Actually I agree / see your point 

(esp. as the result sets are fairly short / restricted somehow, as opposed to say Google where you could end up on page 204 with results that were almost irrelevant)

Unless we hear otherwise today, we'll get the change made tomorrow.

(just wanted you to be aware of the date vs relevance thing, I remember the first time I hit it, it took a little while for the penny to drop as to why just post sorting the results by date wouldn't work - or rather give the outcome I or anyone else was expecting)

Jamie
Jamie, reassigning to you, in case Wahome replies later in the day.
Have reordered, free text results are now in date order (as opposed to relevence order)
Thank you Jamie.

Subtle issue still with search: if searching by 'town or postcode' (not
mere keyword), events ought to be ordered by distance. It seems from the
spec that using parameter DEFAULT would fix this by sorting by either DATE
or DISTANCE as appropriate.

Basically here’s what I am allowed to do to create buttons:

1. Ticketed event checked, ticket price and URL filled in = Book now button

2. Ticketed event checked, “0” entered into Ticket price and URL filled in = Book Free place button

3. Ticketed event unchecked and Ticket URL filled in = Find out more button

Hi Darren,

I replied to Tuesday re. this earlier (see below)

There isnt' really any (official/correct) way to tell the users browser that a PDF should be downloaded rather than opened inline with a plugin or external application, what can only be set by the user in their browser settings.

I suspect what you are suggesting is that we get Apache to serve a application/octet-stream mime type for PDF files, which has the affect of forcing the browser to ask the user what they want to do with file of this type. The danger is that a users browser may (in the past) have attached application/octet-stream to some other application other than a PDF reader.

Jamie

---

How the PDF is handled (ie view in the browser vs download vs view in acrobat) is set by the users browser. I think what you are referring to when you say 'force download' is a trick some sites use of setting the type to something unknown (application/octet-stream is the common one) in order that the browser pops up a dialog and asks the user what they want to do. The downside to this is the users machine won't know it's a PDF file as we've told the browser it's something else (it's only the file extension .pdf that means the PDF sometimes gets reunited with its correct type once downloaded - but this isn't guaranteed)

I would suggest a a more correct solution is to put a comment under the link telling users to right click if they wish to save the file somewhere on their machine.

The solution (of setting an unknown file type) is a hack (we would be deliberately sending incorrect information to the browser, to force the browser to ask us what to do) which may well have its own issues.

--

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

Sorry about this, I wasn’t aware a ticket was already raised about this.

Thanks,

Darren

I should add that we serve a "Content-Disposition attachment" header for PDF's in that folder, which is semi-respected on some browsers.

Although if your browser is manually configured to open PDF's (mime type application/pdf) using either a browser viewer / plugin or an external application, then the Content-Disposition header will probably be ignored. After all if you have specifically told your browser to open PDF in a particular application or way, would you want a website overriding that rule/setting?

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

Funny enough someone just suggested that idea.

Thanks,

Darren

-----Original Message-----

Hi Tuesday,

1/ How the PDF is handled (ie view in the browser vs download vs view in acrobat) is set by the users browser. I think what you are referring to when you say 'force download' is a trick some sites use of setting the type to something unknown (application/octet-stream is the common one) in order that the browser pops up a dialog and asks the user what they want to do. The downside to this is the users machine won't know it's a PDF file as we've told the browser it's something else (it's only the file extension .pdf that means the PDF sometimes gets reunited with its correct type once downloaded - but this isn't guaranteed)

I would suggest a a more correct solution is to put a comment under the link telling users to right click if they wish to save the file somewhere on their machine. 

The solution (of setting an unknown file type) is a hack (we would be deliberately sending incorrect information to the browser, to force the browser to ask us what to do) which may well have its own issues. 

2/ urls / redirects

www.london2012.com and festival.london2012.com are separate domains/sites there is no sensible way of mapping /festival to festival.london2012.com that is transparent to the user.

Although the official URL may be www.london2012.com/festival the site is festival.london2012.com. Not only are they different domain names, they are different web sites, on different servers.

www.london2012.com/festival is simply a redirect to where the site is hosted.

To make the site appear under /festival without the URL changing, we'd actually need to move the site so that it physically lived within the /festival of the main www site (which technically isn't possible)

See also /shop and shop.london2012.com and /tickets an tickets.london2012.com

Hope that makes sense 

Jamie

Sent from my iPad

Hi Jamie


1. When you say put a comment under a link – I don’t think this is possible from our end. We have promoted the brochure on the homepage and I don’t think it would sit well if I write ‘right click to save’ on the copy --- are there any other suggestions?


2. Thanks for the explanation on the URL festival.london2012.com

re. download PDF, I see your problem, but really there is no way to force a browser to download a PDF (it's like asking if we could make the link open in Acrobat on the user machine or for images to open in Photoshop - it's something that is set in the users browser not at the server end when we deliver the page/pdf). As I said there may be some assumption that this can be done, by sending a unknown file type, which may force the users browser to ask them what they want to do with the file, but it is a hack and will cause more issues than it solves.

Jamie

Ok Jamie. I will consult with Claire on this and see if we can cram copy to say to right click and save.

Tuesday

One solution would be to .zip the file up, as most browsers will automatically download a .zip file and/or ask the user if they want to decompress it.

But that may just lead you towards a whole new set of problems ie. users who don't have their machines setup to unzip a file or other users who actually want to view the PDF inline - for example iPad users.

Before you try and cram extra copy in it may be worth seeing how widespread the issues is, the default on most browsers is to ask you what you want to do with a PDF the first time it encounters one and then remember what to do for that file type. 

It is worth remembering that users who see the PDF inline in their browser may have actually selected that behaviour specifically / want that behaviour (ie. users on an iPad). It is also worth bearing in mind that for an individual user the way PDF's are handled (by their browser) on the Festival site will be exactly the same as they are handled on other sites.

I realise the brochure has lots of extra information in it and it's nice to have a PDF you can browse offline on a tablet device like an iPad (I often find that an overview or daily PDF I can print out is especially useful at festivals and conferences). But I am still slightly confused by is why, when you have a lovely website that is searchable by event / date / region along with up to date editorial content, are you directing users towards what is basically a PDF of a print publication :-)

Jamie

Hi Jamie

Thanks for the insight – these are instructions from the big bosses to direct people to go see and download the brochure. I would of course want people to just explore the website because the information is more up to date.

Many thanks for always giving a prompt reply. I will keep investigating to see if the same problem persists.

Tuesday

After the realization that Akamai was sharing one cache among all of the redirected sub-domains, and the resulting problems regarding users being unexpectedly redirected, we removed this behaviour last week.
Kirsten & Russ are currently managing Akamai being reconfigured to have one cache per sub-domain in order to achieve the required behaviour.
I believe this is being set up on the staging Akamai instance first but I don't know how far they have got (I am waiting until I hear from Kirsten before re-enabling the redirects).
It should be re-enabled on production before the end of the week (I would hope an awful lot sooner, but much of it is out of Kitsite's hands!).
Kieran

> virus-free. The sender does not accept liability for any errors or
> omissions.
>
> http://www.london2012.com
>
> ________________________________

Kirsten, this isn't something we can implement straight away. Can we presume that the FTP server will continue to be available for at least a few days please?
Kieran

Yes, if you need a few more days then that'll be fine.  Could someone test you can login and access it now though before you implement change?

Thanks
Kirsten

<hr width="100%">

http://www.london2012.com
<hr width="100%">
I think they would like to turn the FTP server off next Friday.

Hi Kirsten,
We will aim for this, but I have been having some problems connecting; I think it might be SSL version incompatibility so it might take a little while to fix. Please can we we request that FTP isn't switched off until we've given our explicit acknowledgement that we're ready to go?
Thanks,
Kieran

Actually ... it would make it a lot quicker for us to implement if we could use public key authentication rather than username/password authentication. Is this in any way feasible?
Thanks,
Kieran
It’s not something we can quickly implement or that we’re keen to do. If you really have no way around it then we’ll do another impact assessment and take it from there.
I have told GDP not to turn off the FTP server until we tell them it is OK to do so.

Hi Kirsten,
We are now using the SFTP server.
If possible I would rather wait until Monday before switching off the FTP server, to give us a good test run first.
Kieran
Set to 0.8 days as I had to install new perl modules, manually making them, testing, etc.
Are we good to switch this off on Monday?

Hi Kirsten,
As far as we are concerned, the files are being retrieved successfully and the events are being uploaded to the website. For a definitive opinion, it might be worth contacting the Festival team (to double-check that their additions/changes have been making it through to the live site). However as long as GDP assure you that they are pushing all changes to the SFTP server in the same way as they were pushing to the FTP server then I am sure all is ok!
Sorry for the ambiguous response. Basically, I'm saying it all looks good from where we're sitting!
Kieran
Thanks

Hello,

Urban Classic
Thursday 5 July 2012, 6pm
Waltham Forest Town Hall
 www.walthamforestbig6.co.uk

On 24 Apr 2012, at 18:19, David Bradley wrote:

The main body of copy is uploaded, but the summary is too long, as the 100 characters limit includes spaces.  Apologies, I should have made that clearer.

From: Anna Doyle [mailto:anna@annadoyleprojects.com]
Sent: 24 April 2012 18:05
To: David Bradley
Subject: Re: CREATE The Barking Bathhouse copy for website

Hi David

This copy does need to be amended:  here  is the summary copy:

Urban Classic Featuring Fazer, Ms Dynamite, Devlin, Skepta and the BBC Symphony Orchestra conducted by Jules Buckley
Free ticketed event

Thursday 5 July 2012, 6pm
Waltham Forest Town Hall

A genre-busting music extravaganza on Thursday 5 July when the modern urban styles of Fazer, Ms Dynamite, Devlin and Skepta collide with the world-renowned BBC Symphony Orchestra for Urban Classic. Part of Waltham Forest's 'Big 6' celebrations.
Hosted by Waltham Forest Council. Supported by CREATE.
Produced by Bigga Fish and Serious in partnership with the Barbican and the BBC Symphony Orchestra.
www.walthamforestbig6.co.uk
www.createlondon.org




On 24 Apr 2012, at 17:24, David Bradley wrote:


Certainly.  I literally pressed send as your second email arrived.

As a reminder, the summary has to be a maximum of 100 characters.  The main body 400 words.

The copy reads:

A meeting of musical cultures featuring some of the biggest names in UK urban music.

Urban Classic is a meeting of musical cultures, bringing together the BBC Symphony Orchestra with leading artists from the UK's urban music scene. As part of the Music Nation weekend, this event will be the first performance of new arrangements by Ayanna Witter-Johnson and Jason Yarde. For Urban Classic, the BBC Symphony Orchestra will be conducted by Jules Buckley, fresh from his collaboration with Basement Jaxx and the Metropole Orchestra, where he is Principal Guest Conductor.

Part of the BBC's Music Nation, uniting orchestras, musical groups, choirs and concert halls all over the UK.

Best,

David.

From: Anna Doyle [mailto:anna@annadoyleprojects.com]
Sent: 24 April 2012 17:22
To: Tuesday Gutierrez; David Bradley
Cc: kym@createlondon.org Bartlett
Subject: CREATE The Barking Bathhouse copy for website
Importance: High

Please can we be sent the link to circulate to partners before this is live.

If this copy needs to be edited please can you confirm word count and we can send over revised copy.


The Barking Bathhouse, Something & Son

CREATE in partnership with LB Barking & Dagenham and the Mayor of London.

CREATE has commissioned Something & Son - the design practice behind the hugely
successful FARM:shop in Dalston - to design and build The Barking Bathhouse. Focusing on
wellbeing the Bathhouse will experiment in the latest health and beauty ideas and technologies
with an overall aim of helping people feel happy and relaxed this summer.
The pavilion will combine a spa with a bar where the public will be able to sip healthy cocktails
and smoothies under a canopy of growing cucumbers and sunbathe amongst piles of industrial
debris. After soaking up vitamins and being pampered with unusual treatments visitors will
sweat it out then cool down in the engine room - a sustainable steam room and pioneering 'dry
ice' chiller. The purpose-built design will take influence from the 20th century working man's
bathhouse, ultra modern spa treatments and Barking's industrial heritage to bring a new
dimension to Barking town centre.

www.createlondon.org

Anna Doyle
Producer

CREATE,

t:  + 44(0) 207 382 7284

m:  + 44 (0) 7958 718 186

For example, if you type in Bradford it brings up BBC Three Gala which is broadcast nationwide. We're getting a lot of complaints. We need to get this fixed asap.




Best regards

Tuesday Gutierrez
Digital Marketing Executive
London 2012 Festival<http://www.london2012.com/festival>
Direct line: +44 (0) 30 2012 1427
Fax: +44 (0) 203 2012 001
Mobile: +44 (0) 77 2012 1397

Hello (CC Wahome),

I'm afraid we have no control over whether "nationwide" events are included in the search.
We just display the results that a returned from the GDP search API.
I think at some point they might have been instructed to return nationwide events, even if a specific location is being searched on (I presume the reasoning being that BBC Three is available in Bradford and is thus accessible to residents of Bradford).
If you want the events to be removed from the search then GDP will need to be (re-)instructed, You might - instead - want to consider adding a prominent logo to indicate "nationwide" events?

In case you're wondering, we (Kitsite) can't simply omit results that are "nationwide" events, as then the totals and the paging (which we obtain from the GDP API) would all be out.

Please let us know how you would like to proceed.

Kind regards,

Kieran
Ok thanks a lot. I have flagged this to Wahome and we will just change the order of the search results

Hi Jamie

Tuesday

[cid:image001.jpg@01CD1EEB.DD2D3E10]

Hi Tuesday,

1) Publication

Ah, I think I know what has happened, we had to republish all the published articles to turn on the Facebook comments.

We don't actually have an easy way to revert to a previous version, we may be able to find the text form an old log file, but there is no easy way to revert to a previous version, do you want us to try and find the previous body copy for you or do you know what changed / have a copy of the old text.

Sorry we should have told you we were planning to republish pages. In future, if you do have articles that you plan to leaving modified (but un re-publishd) for long periods of time it's best to 'lock' them (right click and select lock) that way they can't be published by any bulk publication - although that does have it's own problem in that those pages won't be picked up by a bulk republication run and so may end up out of sync with the rest of the site). "New" articles will never be published accidentally, it;s only modified pages that will get published if we run a bulk publish across the site.

2) New user

Can you send a separate ticket with the name and email of the person you need an account setup for and we'll get that setup./

Jamie
